page.title: 02THE VILLAGE OF EAST LANGDON
page.content: East Langdon is of Anglo-Saxon origin. The name Langandune meaning "At the long hill" first appears in 861. It did not appear in the original Survey though the now extinct manor of Pesinges, origin of the name of Poison Down and Wood, did. Well_established by the 12th century the village has a church dating from that time. Other large buildings include a Primary School, with 13 children aged 5-11,a village hall,a general store and a riding school. In this old farming village there are also 2 farmhouses,13 barns, 11 grain silos and numerous sheds. Few of the 221 people who live in the area of the village are employed in farming. They live in 61 houses 19 of which are maintained by the council. The main recreations are gardening,DIY and handicraft. Other interests are very diverse.
